longDescription: Sake (ÈÖí), also known as O-miki (Âæ°Á•ûÈÖí, 'honored sacred sake') in ritual contexts, is sacred rice wine that plays a central role in Shinto worship and Japanese mythology. According to legend, sake brewing was taught to humanity by the kami. The beverage is considered a gift from the gods and a medium for communication between the human and divine realms. Sake is offered daily at Shinto shrines, used in purification ceremonies, wedding rites, groundbreaking ceremonies, and seasonal festivals. The drink appears in numerous myths: Susanoo used sake to intoxicate the eight-headed serpent Yamata-no-Orochi before slaying it; sake features in agricultural festivals honoring the rice harvest; and it is consumed during kagura (sacred dance) performances. The brewing process itself is considered sacred, with brewers observing ritual purity. Sake represents the transformation of rice (gift of the kami) into divine nectar, symbolizing the connection between agriculture, spirituality, and community.

shortDescription: Sacred rice wine offered to kami and consumed in Shinto rituals

mythologyContexts.usage: Sake serves as a sacred bridge between humans and kami. In Shinto practice, sake is offered to deities at shrines, consumed during rituals to receive divine blessings, and shared communally to strengthen social and spiritual bonds. The drink's intoxicating properties are seen as allowing communion with the divine realm. Sake is essential in life cycle events (births, weddings, funerals), agricultural festivals, and purification ceremonies. The toast 'Kanpai!' derives from ritual sake drinking.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Sake represents the divine transformation of nature's bounty (rice) into spiritual nectar. The fermentation process mirrors spiritual transformation and purification. The clarity of refined sake symbolizes purity of heart and intention. Sharing sake creates musubi (spiritual connection) between participants and with the kami. The intoxicating effect represents transcendence of ordinary consciousness and entry into sacred time. The eight-fold brewing (yae-shio-ori) used against Yamata-no-Orochi represents perfection and sacred completion.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Sake remains integral to Shinto practice and Japanese culture. Every shrine maintains sake offerings, and major shrines have dedicated sake breweries. The sake brewing season coincides with winter, when spiritual energy is concentrated. Many sake brands bear names of kami or sacred places. The drink marks all significant life events and social gatherings. Sake barrels (kazari-daru) are displayed at shrines and ceremonies. The craft of sake brewing is considered a sacred art, with master brewers (toji) holding respected positions. Modern sake culture maintains ancient ritual connections while evolving as culinary art.
